articles.headline: Citigroup’s Chief Rebuffed on Pay by Shareholders
articles.snippet: Citigroup’s shareholders voted down an endorsement of the bank’s plan to award its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, $15 million in compensation, in a show of frustration about Wall Street pay.
articles.abstract: Citigroup’s shareholders voted down an endorsement of the bank’s plan to award its chief executive, Vikram Pandit, $15 million in compensation, in a show of frustration about Wall Street pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a stinging rebuke, Citigroup shareholders rebuffed on Tuesday the bank’s $15 million pay package for its chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, marking the first time that stock owners have united in opposition to outsized compensation at a financial giant.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Nelson D. Schwartz

articles.headline: In Agent Scandal, Inquiry Leads to Colombian Bordellos
articles.snippet: Investigators are searching for as many as 21 women who are believed to include prostitutes and to have spent the night with a group of security officers.
articles.abstract: Investigators are searching for as many as 21 women who are believed to include prostitutes and to have spent the night with a group of security officers.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARTAGENA, Colombia — At the Ligueros Club, one of many busy bordellos in this seaside tourist city, prostitutes dressed in lingerie wait for a bell to ring, signaling the arrival of men on the prowl. But the next group of American visitors to walk in the door may not be customers at all.
articles.byline: By William Neuman and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Carriers Warn of Crisis in Mobile Spectrum
articles.snippet: As data usage multiplies on mobile devices, carriers say they need more spectrum, but scientists and engineers say newer technologies can improve efficiency.
articles.abstract: As data usage multiplies on mobile devices, carriers say they need more spectrum, but scientists and engineers say newer technologies can improve efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile and Sprint say they need more radio spectrum, the government-rationed slices of radio waves that carry phone calls and wireless data.

articles.headline: Sony Plans Major Cuts in EMI Jobs
articles.snippet: A report that Sony gave to investors this year calls for major job cuts at EMI, the music publishing company that it is buying.
articles.abstract: A report that Sony gave to investors this year calls for major job cuts at EMI, the music publishing company that it is buying.
articles.lead_paragraph: The European Commission is expected to issue a ruling on Thursday in one of the music industry’s biggest deals in the past decade: Sony’s proposed $2.2 billion takeover of EMI Music Publishing.

articles.headline: Frenzied Hours for U.S. on Fate of a China Insider
articles.snippet: A Chinese official who said he had information about Bo Xilai sought and was denied asylum at an American Consulate in China, ensnaring the Obama administration in a politically sensitive episode.
articles.abstract: A Chinese official who said he had information about Bo Xilai sought and was denied asylum at an American Consulate in China, ensnaring the Obama administration in a politically sensitive episode.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the evening of Feb. 6, a vice mayor of a major Chinese city who had a reputation as a crime fighter turned up at the American Consulate in Chengdu in an agitated state, telling a tale of corruption and murder that has ensnared the Obama administration in a scandal it wants nothing to do with.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Competition Needs Protection
articles.snippet: Some fear that a price-fixing lawsuit might give Amazon a pass to offer discounts that could put its competitors out of business.
articles.abstract: Some fear that a price-fixing lawsuit might give Amazon a pass to offer discounts that could put its competitors out of business.
articles.lead_paragraph: To believe publishers and authors, the government just handed Amazon a monopoly over the book market: The price-fixing suit against Apple and the nation’s top publishers filed by the Justice Department last week will free Amazon to offer ruinous discounts in the booming new market of electronic books, drive brick-and-mortar bookstores out of existence and kill off publishers’ lucrative business of ink on paper.

articles.headline: Romney’s Critique of War Policy Gets a Closer Look
articles.snippet: As he moves to focus on President Obama as his sole opponent, Mitt Romney will likely be expected to offer a more precise position on the war in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: As he moves to focus on President Obama as his sole opponent, Mitt Romney will likely be expected to offer a more precise position on the war in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney has made Afghanistan a showcase for his attacks on President Obama’s foreign policy. He says Mr. Obama has undercut American interests by setting timetables for withdrawing troops, providing the Taliban — who displayed their resilience with attacks over the weekend — further reason to wait things out. He called Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta “misguided and so naïve” for announcing plans to hand over primary combat responsibilities to Afghan forces next year and leave American troops mainly in training and other roles.

articles.headline: Device Malfunction Casts Doubt on Industry Pledge
articles.snippet: Issues that dogged heart device makers seven years ago are resurfacing over a problem with a defibrillator wire made by St. Jude Medical.
articles.abstract: Issues that dogged heart device makers seven years ago are resurfacing over a problem with a defibrillator wire made by St. Jude Medical.
articles.lead_paragraph: As doctors scramble to understand the risks posed by a flawed heart device component made by St. Jude Medical, the episode is raising a bigger question — whether the $10 billion heart device industry has fully embraced promised safety reforms.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Katie Thomas
